body: That's an odd mapping. Have you tried ConvertUsing? I would think you'd want every short -> short? to have the same logic.
@jbogard Yea looks like the Nullable change conflicts with MapFrom's expressions that aren't simple cases.

Yes, it is a strange mapping.  :)

I'll look to see how many cases we've got that fall into this to see if ConvertUsing is an option.
Another option is to use ResolveUsing - that's Func based instead of Expression based. AutoMapper tries to rewrite the expressions to be null-safe, which doesn't look like what you want.

@jbogard The fix to this would be something similar to #1482.  Have to change the (short)0 from to (short?)0. based on binary operator.

@ccbristo About seal having better diagnostics.  I don't think they should, since they are going deep into the internals and it's usually something wrong with AutoMapper that needs to be fixed vs something wrong with how user used it.  Seal should never fail, but obviously it did, so IDK.
@TylerCarlson1 I wonder if the more obvious fix is to only rewrite the expression to handle nulls for flattening redirection. If it's only member access. I'm not sure.
@TylerCarlson1 I had similar thoughts, especially since one of the exceptions came from within the BCLs.  But during this initial upgrade, it would sure be nice!

With option number 2, #1469 would fail. It failed because the null was translated to a 0, then set on the nullable to 0 as opposed to null.

Part of the problem here are nullables, and that I can't use a null propagating operator in expressions. That would _greatly_ simplify things, but alas, it isn't there.

No option 2 wouldn't fail #1469 cause it's flattening and option 2 doesn't change flattening logic, just CustomExpressions eg. MapFrom, where these new issues are coming from.
CustomExpression will do null propagation like it did before #1469 where as flattening will keep it's fix for that PR.

Also as far as I know the Elvis operator is just shorthand for what we are doing now.  The REAL annoyance is that you can compare int to int? and the compiler can figure it out, but with expressions you have to manually do the conversions yourself.

issue.title: CustomExpressions don't use dest type and have nullable logic
Exception when configuring mappings (worked in 4.2.1)
issue.body:
Since upgrading to 5.0.2 it seems one of my mappings in throwing the following exception - 
`Expression of type 'System.Nullable`1[System.DateTime]' cannot be used for return type 'System.DateTime'`

The destination property is a nullable date time and the mapping is as follows -
`ForMember(Function(dest) dest.EndDate, Sub(opt) opt.MapFrom(Function(src) If(src.ExamType = ExamType.Makeup, src.ExamSchedules.Max(Function(m) m.Schedule.DtEnd), src.ExamSchedules.Where(Function(f) f.Schedule.BHide = False).Max(Function(m) m.Schedule.DtEnd)))).`

If I try to change the destination to just Date then the configuration doesn't throw an exception but I will get an exception later on when my code is run that uses the mapping because there are times where there are no values and it should be null.

Not sure if there is something I'm missing or whether this is a bug or already discussed.

body: This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
